data.title: Teochew Restaurant Huat Kee
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Signature Braised Abalone, Duck Combination, Signature Suckling Pig, Signature Fried Kway Teow, Suckling Pig, Signature Cold Crab, Braised Boneless Duck, Homemade Prawn Balls, Yam Paste
data.ABOUT:
Clean, light flavours and precise cooking that highlights the very best of an ingredients natural flavours: that is the heart and soul of Teochew cooking. At Teochew Restaurant Huat Kee, this informs every dish, from its humblest items, like seasonal vegetables, to its more exquisite ones, like precious ocean bounty.
An award-winning restaurant that has been passed down for three generations of Teochew chefs, Huat Kee is known and loved for its preservation of heritage Teochew flavours, but also its confidence in working with ingredients from far-flung places like Chile and South Africa. Enter the abalone, one of the signature ingredients at this restaurant, and some say done to perfection here. Served braised with sea cucumber, it may not taste like much, but it’s days in the making, and when eaten, is pillowy, soft, and bursting with briny goodness. There’s also Teochew-style duck, braised and served sliced on a platter with stewed pork belly, marinated eggs, tofu, and a lashing of sweet, herbal gravy. Steamed Pomfret, a Teochew hallmark, and one of the restaurant’s signatures, arrives shiny and pearlescent on the table, strewn with fine aromatic garnishes, and a light poaching liquor. The meat gives way in firm but perfectly tender chunks. For truly festive occasions, a whole, glistening, crisp-skinned suckling pig is available, too, and the meal is best rounded off with some signature Yam Paste, cooked with lard to perfection and topped with stewed pumpkin and gingko nuts.
 A mix of humble fare prepared to perfection, and premium ingredients prepared with masterful simplicity: Teochew Restaurant Huat Kee is a heritage restaurant, of the best in Asia, and available at your doorstep. (Jul 2017)

data.title: Teppan Bar Q
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Pet Friendly, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Q Potato Salad, Tonpei Yaki, Squid with Pesto, Gizzard with Habanero Sauce, Bari Bari 2 Pound Steak, Garlic Rice, Duck with Spring Onion, Tiger Prawn with Balsamic Sauce, Mix Seafood
data.ABOUT:
There’s something about Mary teppanyaki at Teppan Bar Q. Take a seat in front of the counters, behind which skilled chefs wield their spatulas with aplomb, and prepare for a meal that’s part performance part gastronomic guilty pleasure. It doesn’t matter that you’re rubbing shoulders with veritable strangers in the intimate space; in a strange way, the hubbub creates a bubble of privacy in which you can fully enjoy flavours.
As the grill fires up, start by scooping up their signature Potato Salad and Roasted Hakata Mentai before moving on to more unctuous plates. Sample Mix Seafood, Tiger Prawn with Balsamic Sauce, and Foie Gras with Japanese Radish, or meats such as the Duck with Spring Onion and Angus steak. Teppan Tapas are perfect for lighter bites like Squid with Pesto and Sauteed Mushrooms with Garlic whilst fans of okonomiyaki or omelettes will benefit from the Hakata Tonpei Yaki menu. This isn’t a restaurant aiming for sterile food and reverent silence so if you’re after a convivial atmosphere and fuss-free selections of grilled gems, you’re definitely on the right track! (May 2016)

data.title: Teppan Chef's Table
data.Good For: City Views, Casual Dining
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Black Angus Beef Tenderloin Donburi, Miso Atlantic Salmon Donburi
data.PRESS RELEASE:
This private chef's table experience lets you get up-close-and-personal with the culinary action over a teppanyaki communal table. With a menu that changes according to seasonality, you're always guaranteed the freshest produce and diverse offerings.
The restaurant's 'Weekday Donburi Lunches' are a steal, starting from just $22++ for a hearty Japanese donburi (rice bowl) that comes complete with a salad, miso soup and fresh fruits. (Mar 2019)

data.title: Teppan Kappou Kenji
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Drinks, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Wagyu Minced Katsu, Grilled Avocado with Herbs & Cheese, Soft Tofu Skin with Sea Urchin, Premium A5 Miyazaki Wagyu Sirloin, Shimanto River Unagi, Japanese Oyster from Mie Prefecture, Japanese Lobster from Mie Prefecture (Isejingu Hono)
data.ABOUT:
Riding the wave of the Omakase craze in Singapore is this elegant restaurant in Tanjong Pagar. Established in a refurbished shophouse and seating less than 50, this intimate eatery serves up fresh sukiyaki, sashimi, and sushi made with fresh ingredients sourced directly from Japan.

However, the true highlight of this spot is that it is the perfect place to indulge in some Omakase dishes that can be tailor-made according to your preferences. Diners can give celebrated Japanese chef Kenji Okumura guidance on their desired ingredients and flavours, and in a “reversed” Omakase experience, the chef will do his best to incorporate them in a bespoke menu. With ingredients sourced directly from Japan, and with all new ingredients chosen specifically by Chef Okumura, diners can rest assured that they will be in good hands at this restaurant. 

The Omakase menu makes use of ingredients from various regions of Japan, such as Iseshima oysters, Ise Ebi and Akamoku seaweed from the Mie Prefecture, Unagi from Shimanto and other fresh produce imported directly. Having satisfied personalities such as Gorbachev, Wen Jiabao, and the Japanese Emperor himself with his Omakase creations, diners are sure to enjoy the creations of Chef Okumura. (Nov 2018)

data.title: Teppan Works
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Drinks
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Hokkaido Uni with Aji-tama, Signature Cheese Okonomiyaki, Wagyu Ribeye, Special Okonomiyaki (Pork and Beef Tendon), Warabi Mochi
data.ABOUT:
Tucked away in Tras Street, Singapore’s Japanese enclave, Teppan Works is a cosy spot that offers diners a taste of Osaka. The Japanese city is well-known for its popular okonomiyaki dishes, and you’ll find this a mainstay on the menu at Teppan Works. Try the Signature Cheese Okonomiyaki, made from your choice of sharp gorgonzola, a light buffalo mozzarella, creamy camembert, or a rich raclette. The cheese is then cooked into the Japanese savoury pancake, with a crack of black pepper and a dash of fiery chilli oil. For something a little meatier, the Special Okonomiyaki is a must-try. The pancake here is stuffed with juicy slices of pork belly and beef tendon, mixed with potato and a fried egg for an indulgent treat.

Otherwise, order a slab of the Wagyu Ribeye for sharing — the beef is cooked simply over the grill, then served with a dash of salt and pepper to bring out the rich, buttery flavours of the cut. For dessert, save space for the restaurant’s signature Warabi Mochi. Made with fine kinako (roasted soy bean) powder and black sugar syrup, these fluffy little pillows are the perfect sweet treat to end a delicious meal. (Apr 2019)

data.title: Tess Bar & Kitchen
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Drinks, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Duet Scallop & Aburi Tartare, Crispy Pork Belly, Triple Truffle Frites, Tess Wagyu Cubes & Bone Marrow, Baeckeoffe, Homemade Duck Rillette, Bohemian Vegetables Love, Chocolate Fondant with Blueberry Compote
data.ABOUT:
Tess Bar & Kitchen is the always-bustling, perennially fun filled spot you might have seen on Seah Street near Raffles Hotel. And with drinks from an award-winning mixologist, matched with trendy fare from a culinary heavy-hitter, it's easy to obsess over Tess.
Like any it-girl, or it-restaurant for that matter, Tess has a distinctive style, swagger and can back it all up with bona fide coolness. That confidence comes from tatted-up head chef Martin Wong, with L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon kitchen cred and whose expertise in fine dining and playful personality comes through in a variety of small, medium and large plates, which vary in fanciness, but all aim to satisfy.
Behind the bar, you can find the shaken-up creations of Steve Leong, the well-known finalist of Diageo Reserve World Class' Singapore 2013. That means that the cocktails are as fine as the dining at Tess, whether you go with old world classics or newfangled tipples. He's not alone in dreaming up drinks, however, as Tess plays host to the city's up and comers in the bar scene, in what turns out to be an open mic night of sorts, that the regular patrons, and there are a lot of them, love.
Settle into the hip, glowy space that's configured for optimal hanging out. From the menu, the Duet Scallop & Aburi Tartare shows off Tess' fancier side, with scorched meaty scallops played against a refreshing chopped tartare. Also from the small plates, the Crispy Pork Belly is simplistic in its flavour, served with a fusion dip, forming a savoury, finger-licking good dish. From the Medium Plates, the Tess Wagyu Cubes & Bone Marrow is a surefire winner, with pan seared cuts of beef glazed with veal jus and marrow, just in case you needed more of a meat hit.
It's not all about the carnivores, though, as a selection of cheeses and even Vegan mains (a rare sight at Singapore fine dining restaurants, let alone a bar) can satisfy meatless diners. From that section, the Bohemian Vegetables Love is a colourful tangle of grilled zucchini, capsicum, aubergine and a piquant red pepper coulis. Finally, from the limited selection of dessert, the Chocolate Fondant with Blueberry Compote shows that the kitchen keeps careful measure of foodie trends, with savoury elements of spicy apple crumble accenting the luscious classic cake.
In the end, it's not just the good looks and impressive resume at Tess that will have you coming back for more, but the rotating food and drinks menu of creative selections. In fact, you are sure to learn what other fans already know: when it comes to Tess, just say yes. (Dec 2014)

data.title: Thai Accent
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Kid Friendly
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Tom Yam Seafood Soup, Green Curry, Steamed Seabass, Mango with Sticky Rice
data.PRESS RELEASE:
Located in Vivo City, overlooking Sentosa Island. Thai Accent will surely amaze you with Thai cuisine like never before. The moment you step into the restaurant, you will not only be greeted with warm Thai hospitality but also a stylish and funky giving it a retro and clean feeling to this iconic restaurant. 
The menu offers a simple yet tasteful selection of Thai cuisine. There are a number of omissible items, including the superb Tom Yam Seafood Soup with spices that will surely leave a tingling feeling on your taste buds. For a totally unique Thai cuisine experience, give Green Curry a try, carefully blended herbs with a light touch of coconut cream, served with a choice of chicken or beef. 
Another signature dish is our Steamed Seabass with lime, garlic and chili sauce. This is a sublime explosion of taste combining sweetness of the fish and sourness and spiciness of its accompaniment of chili, lime, garlic and other herbs.
Conclude your meal with a traditional dessert of Mango with Sticky Rice will surely give an ‘accent’ to a satisfied meal. (Jan 2018)

data.title: Thai Tanic Hotpot
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Snow Crabs, Lobsters, Abalone, Blood Clams
data.ABOUT:
Seafood lovers, rejoice! With a table to table deshelling service, free-flow snow crab legs, and a variety of fresh seafood from an affiliated nursery brought in daily, this restaurant is a must-visit for anyone who enjoys the treasures of the sea. Not a fan of seafood? Fear not, as there is a range of sliced-to-order shabu shabu meats, greens fried upon order, and several other cooked dishes to tickle your tastebuds. Once you’re stuffed to the gills with the meats on offer, fill up with dessert options including Belgian Waffles, artisanal cakes and floral teas. 

With ample al-fresco seating, lush interiors and avant-garde decor, as well as a decadent VIP Room just for guest events, this restaurant is the perfect place to go for a fresh, fuss-free seafood dinner with family and friends. (June 2018)

data.title: Thai Wok Restaurant
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Large Parties (16+)
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Thai Prawn Popcorn, Mango Salad, Tom Yum Glass Noodles, Suicide Ginger Chicken, Curry Soft Shell Crab
data.ABOUT:
The glories of Thai street food abound at this unassuming eatery along bustling Cuppage Terrace, calling out to the barflies looking for some comforting grub to ease along the night. With its selection of classic Thai bites, ranging from smokey street food to hearty home-style fare, Ginger Thai has it all.

Tuck into some classic fiery Green Curry, or a savoury-sweet Massaman Chicken Curry featuring tender chunks of chicken cooked in a red curry with seasonal fruit. Or get a plate of the Ginger Signature Wings, aromatic deep fried chicken wings marinated with fragrant ginger spices. For some comfort food, get a serving of Basil Chicken, minced chicken tossed up with chili and holy basil for a heady and spicy kick, perfect over some steaming white rice, or even Black Pepper Glass Noodles, vermicelli noodles marinated in Thai garlic and sauteed with lots of fresh pepper.

Don’t forget the quintessential Tom Yum Soup, served with your choice of seafood or chicken, but either way bursting with the bright, piquant flavours of Thai herbs and spices, and a zesty finishing of lime. If you’re feeling nostalgic, a plateful of Pineapple Rice, perfectly-cooked rice steeped in pineapple, spices, and herbs for a mild, gentle warmth, and lots of savoury-sweet goodness. It’s the perfect foil to all those rich sauces and flavour. This is some of the most authentic Thai food in the heart of town! (Oct 2017)

data.title: Thai'd Me Up
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Green Curry, Stir-Fried Basil Minced Meat, Phad Thai, Tom Yum Hor Fun, Mango Sticky Rice
data.ABOUT:
Thai'd Me Up boasts a menu that brings together the best of Thai cuisine and a dash of modern Singapore flavours. With the head chef hailing from Chiang Mai, one can be sure to expect a wide variety of Thai dishes done right.

Start your meal with classic street snacks such as prawn cakes and grilled chicken skewers. For mains, you'll be spoilt for choice with the array of curries, seafood, meats, and rice and noodle dishes available. Get a mix of traditional Thai fare like Green Curry, Stir-Fried Basil Minced Meat, and Phad Thai, as well as innovative creations such as Cereal Prawn and Tom Yum Hor Fun.

End your meal on a sweet note with a refreshing Mango Sticky Rice or Red Ruby, and wash down all the goodness with a glass of Thai Milk Tea. (Dec 2019)

data.title: Thanying Restaurant
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Khao Ohb Sapparod, Yam Som Oh, Tom Yam Goong, Gaeng Keow, Phad Thai Goong Sod
data.ABOUT:
With delicate partitions and wood accents in the furniture and flooring, this restaurant is the closest you can get to a traditional Thai household without leaving the country. The interior isn’t the only authentic thing here, though. For over three decades, Thanying has filled the stomachs of hungry patrons with Southeast Asian staples fit for royalty.

Start your culinary adventure with the Yam Som Oh, a salad made with sweet pomelo, a generous serving of chicken and prawn, chilli, and topped with tangy lemon juice for an extra edge. This refreshing salad will awaken your taste-buds and prep your tongue for the onslaught of flavours to come. While classics like Tom Yam Goong, Gaeng Keow, and Gaeng Ped are available, the main that truly stands out is Prow Pla Nam Daeng, a hearty soup made with generous chunks of fish maw. 

Looking for something a little moreish? Look no further than the Khao Ohb Sapparod - pineapple fried rice served with juicy chicken pieces and topped with sweet and salty pork floss. The tangy taste of the pineapple gives this dish a fresh tropical twist, while the flavoured pieces of chicken and vegetables add texture and complex flavours to what would otherwise be a regular plate of fried rice. (July 2018)

data.title: The Auld Alliance
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Drinks, Private Functions, Romantic Dates
data.Address: 9 Bras Basah Road#02-02ARendezvous Hotel GallerySingapore (189559)                                                Map
data.PRESS RELEASE:
Beautifully appointed bar in an Heritage Building, The Auld Alliance has one of the largest Whisky
collection in the World with around 1,500 Whiskies. (Jun 2019)

data.title: The Bar at 15 Stamford
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Drinks, Private Functions, Romantic Dates
data.Address: 15 Stamford RoadLobby LevelThe Capitol Kempinski Hotel SingaporeSingapore (178906)                                                Map
data.PRESS RELEASE:
Tinged with a vintage charm, the 80-seater bar is decorated with mahogany-clad and nineteenth century furniture. A long, sleek and wooden-topped bar extends from the entrance and leads into a 10-metre long parquet-floored bar lounge, sporting wood and rattan cushioned bar stools, luxurious plush leather sofas and hanging pendant lamps emitting a warm glow.

Guests have a choice of over 250 labels of wine, such as Chateau Pey La Tour Bordeaux and Astrolabe Sauvignon Blanc. The Bar at 15 Stamford showcases 160 labels of rum, painstakingly sourced from Old and New Worlds. Exclusive to The Bar at 15 Stamford, we have added new additions of rums to our collection. Bottled by The 1423 for its Single Barrel Selection range, we have the Dominican Republic 2008, Trinidad 2008, Cuba 2013 and Panama 2006. These single cask rums have been matured in a single cask for at least 5 to 12 years, and include their individual complex aromas and notes. (Sep 2019)

data.title: The Beacon
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Drinks, Large Parties (16+)
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Chef's Salad, Black Mussels, Wagyu Burger, Lobster Roll, Seafood Stew, Pollo Chicken Pizza, The Captain's Combo, Nachos
data.PRESS RELEASE: An epicurean adventure awaits with fresh fruit martinis, freshly shucked oysters by the bar and music from the city's hottest crooner, Rafi Ali with The Vibes. The Italian menu features comfort from the shores of the Latin peninsula with an emphasis on pastas, panini sandwiches and skinny pizzas. Sleek and smart during the week we roll up our sleeves and loosen our ties on the weekends with spit roasts and ice-cold beer as we take in the breezy afternoons on our sun-kissed terrace. Get ready for The Beacon, get ready for the finer things in life. (Mar 2017)

data.title: The Beast
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions, Large Parties (16+)
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Baconator Shooter, The Beast Burger, Southern Fried Chicken, Shrimp & Grits, Chicken & Waffles, Pulled Pork Hash, Mac & Cheese Burger, Freshly Baked Cornbread, Bourbon Pecan Pie
data.ABOUT:
For a heaping serving of Southern charm in Singapore, there's no place like The Beast off Arab Street. Featuring artisan Bourbon flights and stick-to-your-ribs soul food, it's sure to tame your beast of an appetite.

Wrapped around a corner of Jalan Klapa, The Beast is a pint-sized space with gallons of flavour. Kick-started by local entrepreneur Jamie Koh of The Chupitos Bar fame, the barn-like eatery is an ode to her college days in Atlanta, Georgia. And some fun times those must have been, judging by the heavy influence of Kentucky-sourced bourbon whisky, including their signature and self-explanatory Baconator shot. The narrow ground floor area is raw and rustic, save for a trendy marquee sign along the inner wall. You could also opt for a roomier dining area upstairs, or for an alfresco barrel-topped table along the walking path.

While it's a space built for fun times and honky-tonk, the food takes its tradition of Southern hospitality very seriously. You'd be hard-pressed to find such true-blue Southern specialties as fluffy buttermilk biscuits with sausage gravy and Cajun-spiced shrimp and grits anywhere else in the city, let alone such superb versions. Though the reputation for Southern fare starts with fried chicken and ends with extra butter (Paula Deen-style), The Beast features a complete array of the diverse flavours for which the region is so popular for. If you haven't tried these dishes before, consider this your warning that this stuff is habit-forming, and though not diet-friendly, definitely worth the splurge.

Go for their new brunch menu, when those fresh-from-the-oven biscuits are on display, stuffed with drool-worthy fillings like crispy battered chicken and slow cooked pulled pork. Also noteworthy are the classic Chicken & Waffles, the Mac & Cheese Burger and savoury Cornbread. Washed down with icy Sweet Tea, or all you can drink Mimosas at $30, that's some really good eatin' y'all! (Mar 2017)

data.title: The Blue Ginger (Great World)
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Nonya Fish Head Curry, Beef Rendang, Sambal Bendy, Durian Chendol
data.ABOUT:
Slow down and appreciate the beauty of tradition here at The Blue Ginger. Tucked away in a beautifully restored three-storey shophouse along Tanjong Pagar, the Peranakan restaurant provides a conducive and friendly space for conversation accompanied by hearty food that will satisfy more than your belly. 

Dive into conversation and the unique Pernakan culture with the restaurant’s extensive menu. Prompted by the fond memories of hearty feasts, the menu features a long list of starters, soups, meat, seafood and more. The Nonya Fish Head Curry is a staple. Simmered in a traditional home style curry, the red snapper dish is garnished with lady’s fingers and eggplant. 

A great centrepiece for any occasion, the fish head curry has a subtle taste of coconut milk that adds to the richness of the broth, bringing out the flavour of the fish. Order a Beef Rendang to go with the fish. Perfectly complementing the spiciness of the fish head curry, the tender beef cubes are prepared in rich coconut milk spiced with ginger, lemongrass, lime leaves and a dash of curry powder for a fiery kick. 

Other signature dishes here include the Curry Vegetables, Ayam Goreng Kunyit, Sambal Bendy and Durian Chendol. (Nov 2020)

data.title: The Boiler (Esplanade)
data.Hours: Sun-Thu: 11:30am-2:30pm (Last Order: 2:15pm), 5-9:30pm (Last Order: 8:45pm)Fri-Sat & Eve of PH: 11:30am-2:30pm (Last Order: 2:15pm), 5-10pm (Last Order: 9pm)
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Momma's Scoop, Sweet Potato Fries, Bombdiggity Bag, Signature Lobsicle, Southern Chicks & Waffles, Signature Fish & Chips, Boiler's Ultimate Burger, Prawn Pasta Soup Crispy Prawn Pasta
data.ABOUT:
The Boiler brings the concept of the American seafood boil to its second outlet at the Esplanade, complete with all the traditional spices, side dishes and cracking crustaceans and a stroke of culinary genius called the Lobsicle.

There's casual, and then there's Boiler-style casual. The kind of casual that lets you get down and dirty, in the tastiest way possible, with your meal. The Boiler features a laidback set up, allowing you to choose your fresh seafood to be boiled to order. You can go a la carte, but the Bombdiggity Bag with Dungeness crab, prawns, mussels, sausages and corns offers tons of bang for your buck. Next, choose a sauce ranging from slightly piquant to can't-feel-your-lips spicy. Your sack of goodies is prepared and then poured directly onto the paper-topped table. Formality is tossed aside along with the shells as you dig in to get to every nook and cranny of the succulent seafood, taking the phrase "finger-licking good" very literally. Bibs and phone covers are included.
Located near the tourist attractions like the Singapore Flyer and Merlion, The Boiler is a real find for lunch, when the usual seafood feast is fine-tuned to the mid-day meal. Tidy but still decadent dishes like Signature Fish & Chips, the Ultimate Burger with caramelized onions and Crispy Prawn Pasta Prawn Pasta Soup are great options. Any-time Sides like Salt & Pepper Crispy Chicken, the succulent fried Lobsicle on a stick, Sweet Potato Fries, and Momma's Scoop with an indulgently creamy cheesy dip are all worth the calorie splurge. After all, it's not every day that you get to go elbow deep into amazing Louisiana-style seafood. So head on down and live it up! (Feb 2020)

data.title: The Boiler (Howard Road)
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions

data.title: The Buffet at M Hotel
data.Cuisine: Buffet, International, Seafood, Vegetarian Friendly, Steamboat
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner, Large Parties (16+)
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Herbal Drunken Prawns, Monthly Specialty MSG-free Soup Base, Flower Crab, Durian Pengat
data.PRESS RELEASE:
Indulge in a sumptuous spread of fresh seafood-on-ice such as poached prawns, mussels, and clams, Western delights and Asian favourites. Take a trip down memory lane at our nostalgic heritage corner, and feast on quintessentially Singaporean dishes such as laksa, soto ayam, and more! Prepare to save some rooms for our dazzling dessert selections such as the signature durian pengat, Nyonya kueh, and other sweet delights!

Dinners are a piping hot steamboat affair at The Buffet! Sweeten the MSG-free broths with an impressive selection of fresh seafood such as flower crabs, mussels, clams, and premium steamboat staples such as fresh vegetables, meat and yong tau fu. Don’t miss out on our ‘live’ cooking station dishing out the signature herbal drunken prawn a la minute; it does not get any fresher than this! With the signature durian pengat and wide array of decadent cakes, dainty sweet treats at the dessert station, you can satisfy your sweet tooth here too! (Jul 2019)

data.title: The Butcher's Wife
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Drinks
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Dadinhos, Our Brazilian Ceviche, Sago & Coconut Prawns, Marinated Chicken Thigh Dosa, Moqueca, Chargrilled Australian Wagyu Picanha, Magnum Ice Creams
data.ABOUT: The Butcher's Wife is that rare thing: a cozy backstreet bistro where vibrant colours are matched by dynamic flavours in dishes that enchant the palate while challenging preconceptions. Come and discover the joy of natural wines, the cleansing power of fermented ingredients and the exceptional talent of a chef committed to pushing the boundaries of balanced, gut-friendly, 100% gluten free cuisine. (Jan 2020)

data.title: The Carvery
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Fine Dining, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner
data.PRESS RELEASE:
In line with the local government’s latest initiatives to curb the spread of the covid-19 coronavirus, The Carvery has implemented necessary social distancing measures at our restaurant. In addition to spacing out the seating arrangements, we have taken the additional step of changing our buffet to a temporary a la carte and set menu. While the serving style has changed, the premise has not - The Carvery’s signature roast meats and other beloved favourites remain available on the a la carte buffet menu and will be plated to order and served to you at the table.

The safety and well-being of our guests and staff remain our top priority, and we will continue to provide hospitality as and when it is needed. We seek your kind understanding during this time, that if you must meet for social gatherings, to keep your party small and intimate. With these measures in place, we hope to provide a safe and welcoming environment where you can still enjoy a great meal in good company. (Dec 2020)

data.title: The Chupitos Bar
data.Good For: Drinks
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Green Fairies, Flaming Alien Brains, Truffle Fries, Sweet Potato Fries, Crispy Wings
data.ABOUT:
Raise your shot glasses and experience a night you won’t forget at Chupitos Bar. Bringing the game of shots to a whole new level, Singapore’s only specialised shooters bar is located right smack in the heart of the city.

Have it your way with over 130 power-packed shots that may include candy, fire, tricks, and maybe even some naughty props. If you’re looking to rekindle your childhood memories, try the Paddle Pop shots. Want to forget the night? Breathe in the potent fumes from their Gas Chambers. Get ready to embark on a mind-blowing journey to a place filled with Green Fairies, Flaming Alien Brains, and Drunken Monkeys.

Drop by for Happy Hour. Happening Tuesday to Sunday from 3:30pm - 8:00pm for $6nett and 8:00pm til closing for $10nett, enjoy a round of selected shooters, beers, house pours and highballs at great prices. Don’t fret if you’re late to the party. Go hard or go home the whole night long with a multitude of sweet, savoury and fruity flavours. For bar bites, try the Truffle Fries, Sweet Potato Fries, Crispy Wings and more, and pair up your shots with an array of snacks for a night to remember. (Jan 2021)

data.title: The Clifford Pier
data.Hours: The Clifford Pier Heritage Dim Sum BrunchSat-Sun & PH: 10:30am- 12:30pm (Last Order: 12pm), 1:30-3:30pm (Last Order: 3pm)Gin ParlourTriples & NibblesMon-Sat & PH: 5-10:30pm (Last Order: 10pm)
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Drinks, Romantic Dates
data.Address: 80 Collyer QuayLobby LevelThe Fullerton Bay HotelSingapore (049326)                                                Map
data.ABOUT: Glocal is a poor man’s portmanteau for the glamourous local gastronomy presented at The Clifford Pier at The Fullerton Bay Hotel. How else to describe the dizzyingly gorgeous lobby, fluttering with hushed, 5-star service? You’d never know this spot once harboured one of the city’s original bustling ports of call for maritime trade. Since 1933, ships would be warmly greeted with savoury local specialties dished out by floating hawkers. Honouring that charming bit of history, The Clifford Pier acts as a showstopping backdrop for all-day Southeast Asian nibbles.It’s hard to imagine the glittery shores of Marina Bay hosting anything other than the sleek luxuries it's known for, The Fullerton Bay Hotel being its crown jewel. As such, it’s a lovely thought that The Clifford Pier pays respects to the rich tradition of the Bay’s enterprising currents, showcasing the best that Old Singapore has to offer then and now. And The Clifford Pier isn’t paying tribute with just a local-tinted menu, but rather a fully educated selection including rich Laksa, Soup Kambing, The Pier's Lobster Roll, Heritage Bites and Wagyu Rendang.However the homey cuisine doesn’t collide with the frothy aesthetic of the cavernous dining room. As if plucked from the set of a Baz Luhrmann film, the lushly appointed space is swathed in nautical hues of mineral blues, sandy buffs and rich textures. Under ivory arches with a view of the bay, the familiar cuisine at The Clifford Pier is just the opulence you’d expect from The Fullerton Bay Hotel. (Oct 2016)

data.title: The Coconut Club
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Ayam Goreng Berempah Set, Gado Gado, Homemade Otah, Iga Bakar, Terung Assam Manis
data.ABOUT:
Fuelled by a strong passion and love for Singapore's well-loved dishes, The Coconut Club was set up to bring diners a truly local experience.
Served with a hearty portion of coconut rice, anchovies, peanuts, cucumber, fried egg and sambal, pick from a variety of different sets of ingredients to customise your authentic Nasi Lemak adventure.
Seafood lovers will be happy to know that the restaurant offers a variety of fresh seafood dishes. Don't leave without trying the Sambal Tumis Sotong. Stir-fried in a fiery chilli paste, each piece of squid is coated with the perfect amount of sambal tumis with cherry tomatoes for a great kick. Their Sambal Lala dish is another winner in our books. The Venus clams are doused in a signature secret sauce before being left to sizzle in the pan.
One other noteworthy dish aside from the traditional Chendol and classic Nasi Lemak, is the Homemade Otah. The Coconut Club's rendition in the form of charcoal-grilled fish paste with chunks of batang fish and traditional herbs and spices, wrapped in banana leaf. (Aug 2020)

data.title: The Coffee Academics (Millenia Walk)
data.Cuisine: American, Fusion, All-Day Breakfast, Vegetarian Friendly, Cafe, Pizza, Burgers
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Drinks, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Crispy Fish Fillet Tacos, Academics Pancakes Tower, The Academics Breakfast, Banana French Toast, Halloumi & Avocado Salad
data.ABOUT:
An award-winning and dynamic specialty coffee concept from Hong Kong, The Coffee Academïcs is pioneering a new wave of coffee concepts – where boundaries are pushed, blends are perfected and beans are brought to flavourful life, all within the most stylish and social of café backdrops. Sourcing world-class coffee beans with a score of 92 to 94 points by the World Coffee Review – a “Robert Parker’s Wine Advocate” of the coffee world – their beans have achieved the distinct honour of being ranked highest in Asia and top three in the world. Launched in 2015, The Coffee Academïcs is pioneering a new wave of coffee stores in Singapore– where guests can experience a whole new level of dining with an intricate cup of coffee alongside globally-inspired menu offerings.

The smell of freshly roasted coffee hits you as soon as you step into this swish spot, but that’s not the only reason you should come here - their menu is just as enticing as their beverages. Try the Academics Breakfast - it includes every component of a classic American breakfast, but better. Think Maple Bacon, Bockwurst Pork Sausages, and scrambled eggs so creamy they melt in your mouth. For something more wholesome, try the Umami pasta - this dish pays tribute to our garden city by incorporating the familiar local flavour of Hay Bi Hiam (Spicy dried shrimp sambal) into this pasta dish.

Coffee enthusiasts will love seven stations at the Pedder on Scotts outlet. There’s a station for views into the open kitchen where the food is prepared, and a Hand Brew Bar where customers can sit and enjoy hand brewed coffees of single origin. Diners who prefer leaves to beans will love the Tea Academïcs station, where they can enjoy a selection of curated teas. (Jan 2021)

data.title: The Coffee Academics (Raffles City)
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Quiet Dinner
data.Address: 252 North Bridge Road#B1-12Raffles City Shopping CentreSingapore (179103)                                                Map
data.DISHES WE LOVE: The Academics Breakfast, Eggs Ben with Honey Lemon Guac, Banana French Toast, Halloumi & Avocado Salad, Crispy Fish Fillet Tacos, TCA Chilli Dog
data.ABOUT:
If you work in the Central Business District area, this is about to become your new favourite spot. Located in the basement of Raffles City, this incarnation of the luxe Hong Kong specialty coffee concept, featuring a Nitro-stop concept to cater to the go-getters of the city.

Taking Hong Kong by storm in 2012, and arrived on Singapore shores in 2015. Since then, it has become the go-to place for coffee aficionados to get a good brew. And for good reason, too. The coffee made here comes from the top 5% of Arabica beans, and their blend is ranked third worldwide.

The amazing cold brew is featured in their Nitro Coffee which is a pressurised cold brew that is smooth on the tongue and deliciously refreshing - the perfect pick me up for busy mornings. Looking for something moreish? Try the Academïcs Breakfast - it includes every component of a classic American breakfast, but better. Think Maple Bacon, Bockwurst Pork Sausages, and scrambled eggs so creamy they melt in your mouth.
Coupled with the all-time favourite Signature coffee, Okinawa, they've got your #brunchgoals covered.

data.title: The Communal Place
data.Cuisine: American, Australian, Fusion, International, All-Day Breakfast, British, Cafe, Burgers
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Miso Salmon, French Toast, Pancake Tower, Yuzu Chicken
data.ABOUT:
Established around the idea of being a shared location for the community where food, drink and gossip simultaneously occurs, The Communal Place provides diners with the opportunity to unwind, relax and connect over delicious meals of family sized contemporary Western fusion food and great tasting cups of coffee in a relaxing environment. 

Placing social interaction and the idea of family food sharing at the heart of what they do, The Communal Place takes a cue from the strong Peranakan and Eurasian heritage of the local areas and this is aptly reflected in their approach to style of food and portion. A highly recommended chef’s favourite is the Miso Salmon. Served alongside glazed vegetables and mash, the fresh salmon is pan-seared to perfection, making for mouthfuls of tender and juicy meat. For the brunch lovers, the restaurant has a specially curated all day brunch menu that indulges diners in pancakes and French Toast, all day every day. 

Boasting spacious interiors and casual aesthetics, the restaurant is the place to be for brunch, intimate date nights or amazing celebrations. (Jan 2021)

data.title: The Cooperage
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Drinks, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: 12-year-old Glenfiddich, Old Fashioned cocktail, Spicy Prawn And Scallop Aglio Olio, Salmon with Spicy Mentaiko Donburi, Duck Confit
data.ABOUT:
The dim lighting and chocolate-brown leather sofas at this intimate bar sets the mood for a dram (or two) of whisky. Which, of course, is the drink du jour here at The Cooperage. The extensive drinks menu is a tome of bounded pages filled with different whiskies from around the world, starting from affordably-priced 12-year-old malts from Glenfiddich and Glenrothes. You’ll find usual suspects like the Macallans, Hibiki, and Nikka on the menu, as well as rare bottles such as the Bowmore Mizunara. 

On the food front, tuck into canapes, donburi bowls, as well as pastas to go with your smoky spirits. The Spicy Prawn And Scallop Aglio Olio is tossed in a fiery, umami-packed oil, with plump crustaceans served with their heads on so you can suck out all the rich juices. There’s also a creamy Carbonara loaded with generous slivers of fried bacon, and Salmon with Spicy Mentaiko donburi garnished with gleaming ikura pearls. For heartier mains, order the Duck Confit. The fork-tender duck with a crispy skin is swathed in orange sauce, and comes with a fragrant truffle mash and a side salad -- a generous portion that’s enough for two to share. (Feb 2019)

data.title: The Courtyard
data.Hours: North Courtyard : Mon-Sun : 9am-10:30pmA La Carte Menu : Mon-Sun : 11:30am-10:30pm (last order 10.00 pm)Afternoon Tea: Mon-Sun: 3-5:30pm
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Drinks
data.Address: 1 Fullerton SquareThe Fullerton Hotel SingaporeSingapore (049178)                                                Map
data.DISHES WE LOVE: The Fullerton Club Sandwich, The Fullerton Burger, PB Signature Fries.
data.ABOUT:
Located in the Fullerton Hotel Singapore’s sunlit atrium lobby, The Courtyard is the lively setting for a leisure dining with delicious local and international specials or traditional three-tier English afternoon tea of savouries and sweets.
 

In line with government regulations, please note that the sale and consumption of alcohol in all food and beverage establishments are prohibited after 10.30 p.m. daily.

 

The safety and well-being of our guests and team members are our top priority at The Fullerton Hotels and Resorts. We have set up rigorous cleanliness practices and safe distancing measures at our restaurants to ensure that you can experience an enhanced level of protection.(Jul 2020)

data.title: The Dempsey Cookhouse and Bar
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Fine Dining, Drinks, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Egg Caviar, Crispy Salmon Sushi, Rigatoni with Meatballs, Black Truffle and Fontina Cheese Pizza, Roasted Beef Tenderloin, Prosciutto Wrapped Pork Chop, Peach Cobbler, Salted Caramel Ice Cream Sundae
data.ABOUT:
For many foodies, the name Jean-Georges Vongerichten needs no introduction. Best known for his skills as a chef and restaurateur, this culinary superstar owns a deep stable of restaurants that have gathered critical accolades and Michelin stars alike. Lucky for us, Jean-Georges has now created an effortlessly elegant restaurant with The Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar.  

Set in the midst of vibrant COMO Dempsey hub, this 160-seater establishment puts an elegant spin onto Western fare. All the magic happens in its open kitchen where cooking is elevated into a performance art. Notable signature dishes made famous by Jean-Georges appear on the menu here, be it the rich Egg Caviar that’s composed of a warm and oozy egg capped off with caviar and herbs, or the decadent and heavenly Black Truffle and Fontina Pizza. On a hot day, there’s nothing cooler than a bowl of Tomato Gazpacho that’s enhanced with a drizzle of olive oil. Fans of seafood will also appreciate the Maine Lobster, accompanied with baby corn and a smoked chili-almond condiment. And we can’t think of a better way to end the meal than with a glass Lychee Raspberry Bellini.

Refined and elegant, The Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar will be a thrill for anyone who relishes in a dining experience well done. (Aug 2017)

data.title: The Dempsey Project
data.Cuisine: Bar, Modern European, Australian, All-Day Breakfast, Burgers
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Pet Friendly, Private Functions, Large Parties (16+)
data.ABOUT:
Nestled in the barracks of Dempsey hill where the nutmeg plantations once stood tall, The Dempsey Project refuses to be put in a rigid box. Simply because, no matter when you walk in and who with, you are stepping into a place that feels just right.

Once you settle into the communal dining space and pick up a menu, you'll find yourself navigating a boundary-less world of cuisines - from the classic Avo on Sourdough to the flavourful Za'atar Baked Eggs, Ayurvedic Khichdi Wellness Bowl to 9 hour slow-cooked BBQ Pork Ribs, it doesn't get more diverse and wholesome than this. If you're gluten-free, vegan or on a paleo diet, you will not feel marginalized because a hearty offering awaits you too.Open all week long for breakfast, lunch, brunch, afternoon tea, light bites and dinner all week long, their indulgent cheese boards complement a wonderful suite of wines, while their in-house bakery offers guilty and guilt-free pleasure in equal measure. Hosting at home? The team has handpicked small-batch, artisanal produce from all over the world that you can buy off-the-shelf.
 
Our values are our reason to be. We source ethically grown produce that nurtures the livelihoods of communities that cultivate it and the body, mind and soul of those who consume it. (Aug 2020)

data.title: The Dim Sum Place (Bugis)
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Large Parties (16+)
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Baked Bun with Roasted Duck Filling, Molten Salted Egg Custard Bun, Vermicelli Roll with Roasted Duck Cha Shu, Peking Duck Wraps
data.ABOUT:
The idea of halal dim sum may be surprising to some, because really, what is dim sum without the iconic char siew bun or xiao long bao? However, The Dim Sum Place might just change your mind, with its mouth-watering array of Cantonese snacks with a local twist. In fact, with the eatery being flooded with customers every night, we dare say it's been given the Singaporean stamp of approval. 

The menu features an impressive variety of dishes, including steamed, baked, and fried dim sum, noodles, seafood, and roasted meats. Their rendition of the char siew bun is a crowd favourite, with tender braised duck slathered in the same sweet and savoury sauce we all know and love. Other must-try items are the Salted Egg Custard Bun, Vermicelli Roll with Roasted Duck Cha Shu and Herbal Duck. 

Make sure to leave room for dessert too. From comforting yam paste to indulgent honeycomb cakes, you wouldn't want to sit this one out. 

Oh and did we mention it opens till 5am on Fridays and Saturdays? It’s definitely the perfect spot for late-night feasting with your besties. (Nov 2019)

Their rendition of the char siew bun is a crowd favourite, with tender braised duck slathered in the same sweet and savoury sauce we all know and love. Other must-try items are the Salted Egg Custard Bun, Vermicelli Roll with Roasted Duck Cha Shu and Herbal Duck.

Make sure to leave room for dessert too. From comforting yam paste to indulgent honeycomb cakes, you wouldn't want to sit this one out.

Oh and did we mention it opens till 5am on Fridays and Saturdays? It’s definitely the perfect spot for late-night feasting with your besties. (Apr 2021)

data.title: The Dining Room
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Kid Friendly, Quiet Dinner
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Crabmeat Fried Rice, Lobster Spaghetti Arrabiatta, Beef Cheek Rendang, Mee Siam, “Fried or Gravy” Laksa
data.ABOUT:
The Dining Room at Sheraton Towers is proof positive that ground floor dining can be just as panoramic, if not more so, as restaurants perched atop lofty heights. The ambiance is made serene with cascading waterfalls, rock pools, and sculptured gardens just outside the windows; it almost feels like you’ve escaped to another country.

Beneath the high ceilings lies an intimate dining area where diners partake in familiar Asian favourites such as the signature Sheraton Towers "Fried or Gravy" Laksa, Crabmeat Fried Rice and tantalising sweet treats like Ice Burger. (Sep 2020)

data.title: The Dragon Chamber
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Drinks, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Dragon’s Claw, Crocodile Foot braised in Chinese herbs, Wagyu Truffle Hor Fun, Dragon Mountain, Firecracker Chicken, Cheeseburger Eggrolls
data.PRESS RELEASE:
When you arrive looking for The Dragon Chamber, you will find yourself at the entrance of a Kopitiam where patrons are sipping beer and having a bowl of noodles—just an ordinary street food stall. “This must be the place,” you say to yourself. The hostess then gestures you toward the beer fridge as if to offer you a drink. But instead of pulling out a tasty cold brew, the fridge door opens up into a portal into another realm like something out of a real-life Alice in Wonderland. “This is where you must continue alone,” says the hostess, as the fridge door opens into a street alley that transports you into the braised underbelly of the “Long Tang” that is The Dragon Chamber. Things are not always as they appear.
Secretly located within a brightly coloured Kopitiam, The Dragon Chamber is a hidden restaurant. What may look like a regular beer fridge in a kopitiam is actually a secret door that opens up into its own inner recesses. Reminiscent of Chinatown gambling dens and secret society hangouts, the walls of The Dragon Chamber are covered with artwork from local and regional artists such as Sabotage, Mister Tucks, and Riandy Karuniawan, referencing past and recent Chinese tradition from a globalist, counter-culture point of view.
The Dragon Chamber offers an unconventional menu serving “guerilla style” food, representing dishes that are not typical banquet style Chinese food. Among its own wild concoctions from The Dragon Chamber’s test kitchen, the underground restaurant also brings back age-old Chinese dishes that never caught on in mainstream restaurants, because of unconventional ingredients. Yet the flavours are immense. Contrasting lovable Chinese-American recipes, The Dragon Chamber pushes the diner’s comfort zone with adventurous dishes that may even shock diners with unusual Chinese techniques of nose-to-tail animal preparation. One such dish is the Dragon’s Claw. Touted as one of the restaurant’s signature dishes, it features a Crocodile Foot braised in Chinese herbs, served on a bed of greens and a literal ring of fire. Bearing a taste similarly close to chicken, the meat is tender and sweet. Its skin is painstakingly descaled with a torch, revealing a thick and rich layer of collagen that coats the succulent herb-marinated meat with a soft and sticky texture, adding a consistent mouthfeel to every bite. If crocodile foot and mammal innards might be too adventurous for some, we also offer more conventional favourites such as Firecracker Chicken and Wagyu Truffle Hor Fun.
Not a space for political correctness and mellow elevator music, the restaurant recommends not bringing any overtly conservative in-laws you might have. Make your way down to The Dragon Chamber, we dare you to enter the bowels of Chinese cuisine to discover your true gastronomic self. (Sept 2019)

data.title: The Eight
data.Good For: Casual Dining
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Our Bistro Turkey Club, Vegetable Cutlet Burger, Rustica Pizza, Nasi Goreng
data.PRESS RELEASE:
Relish in the perfect combination of gourmet delights, fresh juices and artisanal cocktails in a casual tropical setting. Located on the eighth level of the hotel, the poolside restaurant provides the idyllic backdrop to unwind and relax. Enjoy the summer night breeze as you lounge under the starry sky at The Eight, a modern oasis in the middle of the bustling city. 

 

A fan of wood-fired pizzas from Prego Italian Restaurant? You can enjoy them by the pool at The Eight with Prego Alfresco Menu. (Feb 2021)

data.title: The Elephant Room Singapore
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Drinks, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: 90 Deg Koftar, Spiced Jackfruit Rolls, and Race Course Plantation
data.ABOUT:
Launched in September 2019, The Elephant Room is Singapore’s first culture forward cocktail bar inspired by the city’s vibrant ethnic enclave of Little India. Named after the sub-continent’s national heritage animal, The Elephant Room tells stories of real life figures and experiences through modern tipples concocted with a culinary flair. Helmed by Head Bartender and Co-Owner Yugnes Susela, The Elephant Room is located in a cosy yet visually striking second floor space of a shophouse on the fringes of Keong Saik Road. 

The bar is marking their eventful first year with a new menu of tipples and nibbles. Driven to strike conversations between The Elephant Room and the district’s colourful residents, Yugnes and his team make weekly visits to Little India for more than just supplies. Delving deeper into its colourful past, they seek to uncover and translate its century’s worth of stories, from its European influences to cattle trading, into their menus. (Apr 2021)

data.title: The English House by Marco Pierre White
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Fish and Chips, Honey Roast Belly Pork, Prime Black Angus Beef Wellington, English Egg Custard, Champagne Poached Pear
data.ABOUT:
Touted to be Singapore’s first ‘restaurant with rooms’, The English House is designed to give diners a taste of what it’ll be like dining in the home of British legend Marco Pierre White. Lush green foliage at the entrance gives way to dimly-lit interiors decked with Terry O’Neill photographs, while jazz music plays softly in the background. 
 
From the menu comes British classics like fish and chips and beef wellington. The former is no greasy battered fish served in a newspaper cone; instead, White brings in top-grade English turbot, lightly-battered and served with thick, golden chips cooked in beef fat. Order mains like the Grilled Rib of Black Angus Beef and the Honey Roast Belly Pork Marco Polo to share. The Honey Roast Pork Belly comes piping hot in a claypot, where four generous slabs of unctuous meat lie on a bed of fried kway teow. The smoky rice noodles, together with the marbled meat and crunchy pieces of crackling are a wonderful combination that will keep you coming back for more. 

Save some space for desserts — portions are dainty enough to have one all by yourself. Top picks include a wobbly English Egg Custard that tastes like a refined egg tart, or opt for a lighter dish of Champagne Poached Pear with a luscious creme vanilla. (Feb 2019)

data.title: The Fabulous Baker Boy
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Roast Chicken and Pesto Grilled Cheese Sandwich, Fab Fry Up, Uncle Jimmy’s Fish & Chips
data.ABOUT:
Step into casual and cool vibes here at The Fabulous Baker Boy. A cafe, bakery and restaurant all in one, the eatery presents an all-day breakfast brunch menu and a riveting array of fabulous cakes. Featuring classics with a twist, the expansive menu includes artisanal baked goods such as sourdough bread, croissants, quiches, cookies and cakes.

With more than 14 cakes to choose on, diners will be spoilt for choice. Pair popular menu items such as the Pumpkin and Ricotta Ravioli with Burnt Butter and Sage with delicious smoothies, milkshakes, ice cream and chocolate-based beverages. For the cheese lovers and health conscious, the Roast Chicken and Pesto Grilled Cheese Sandwich is The Fabulous Baker Boy’s house sourdough bread slices filled with a tasty three cheese mix of cheddar, parmesan, mozzarella, roast chicken and herbed pesto. Served with a piping hot bowl of Roasted Tomato or Cream of Mushroom Soup, this delicious brunch menu option is sure to leave diners coming back for more. Other signature brunch menu items include the Cinn Bun Pancakes, Fab Fry Up and Uncle Jimmy’s Fish & Chips. (Jan 2021)

data.title: The Feather Blade @ Tanjong Pagar
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Drinks, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Feather Blade Steak, Burratina, Bak Kwa Martini, Rum Raisin Old Fashioned
data.PRESS RELEASE: True to our mantra of "Proper steaks for the people", we have found ourselves a new home in the heart of Tanjong Pagar Road with a revamped food and beverage menu that would put our old self to shame. Think, your already favourite mains with even more proper sides and sauces, alongside proper cocktails by Diageo World Class winner, Boo Jing Heng. (Mar 2021)

data.title: The Fine Line
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Drinks, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Homemade Crab Cakes, Salt & Pepper Squid, BBQ Baby Back Ribs, Pork Burger, Sharkinator IPA
data.ABOUT:
We like to think ourselves as simple creatures, wanting nothing more than an easygoing night of sharing a hearty meal and cold brew with friends. And that’s where The Fine Line fits in, emerging as one of our favourite hangouts in the bustling neighbourhood of Holland Village.
A gastropub after our hearts, The Fine Line turns out platters of Western food and booze at severely affordable prices. Kick off your night with yummy appetisers such as the Homemade Crab Cakes that come accompanied with a bright mango salsa. You can’t go wrong with the diner’s Salt & Pepper Squid. Here, squid seasoned with salt, pepper, and sugar, is given a quick sauté in garlic chilli. Famished? Then BBQ Baby back Ribs might be up your alley. Available in either half or full rack, these ribs are slathered in a secret (hint: it’s phenomenal) BBQ sauce and served with a side of baked potato, mashed potatoes, or fries. Out of the many bottled beers available, we like the Californian Sharkinator IPA best for its citrusy notes and refreshing aftertaste.
So gather your friends, chomp down on some shared plates of pizzas and fries, and while the night away in this inviting food joint. (Jun 2017)

data.title: The Fortune Cookie
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Private Functions, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Fortune Cookie, Lotus Duck Rice, Beef Ribs Bak Kut Teh, Lobster Laksa Singapura, Merlot Red
data.ABOUT:
Located along Bussorah Street, The Fortune Cookie is a two-storey halal Chinese restaurant eager to bring halal Chinese cuisine to all.

The restaurant features dishes that have been thoughtfully created by the team of Chinese chefs and seeks to introduce yummy fusion dishes to the community. The Peking duck, a staple in Chinese cuisine, is enjoyed best with the Lotus Duck Rice. A delicious mix of sausages and shiitake mushrooms with fried rice, this fragrant dish is topped with a generous amount of Peking smoked duck. Another decadent twist on a local dish is the Beef Ribs Bak Kut Teh. Stewed in a mixture of herbs, spice and Chinese Yam, the ribs are doused in traditional sauce. Pair these lip smacking dishes with the restaurant’s interesting range of halal wines, such as the Merlot Red and Chardonnay White to elevate your dining experience. 

You simply can’t leave without trying the restaurant’s famous Fortune Cookie. Customised to contain a mixture of English lines, popular Singlish phrases as well as well-known Malay proverbs in English, these fortune cookies are specially crafted to spark conversations between friends and families. (Oct 2020)

data.title: The Gallery Bistro
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, City Views, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.Address: 1 St Andrew's Road #01/12/13/14 & 17City Hall WingNational Gallery SingaporeSingapore (178957)                                                Map
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Pancake, Omelette, Beef Cheek Bourguignon, Mushroom Risotto, Double Chocolate Fudge Cake
data.ABOUT:
The place to be to enjoy a scrumptious breakfast, a romantic brunch date or after-work socials, The Gallery Bistro is a museum cafe tucked in National Gallery that has delicious dishes in store for you, any time of the day. 


Drop by in the mornings to have a hearty breakfast with a cup of aromatic coffee as you admire the beautiful views of Singapore’s skyline. Start your day right with a plate of sweet treats. A fluffy stack of pancakes dressed with chantilly cream and fresh berries, add a scoop of the restaurant’s house-made bread and butterfly ice cream for the ultimate indulgence. For those looking for a healthier option, the Omelette comes with a side of Mesclun Green Salad. 


Other well-loved items on the menu include the Beef Cheek Bourguignon, Mushroom Risotto and Avocado on Toast. The dessert menu at The Gallery Bistro also boasts a number of decadent cakes that will surely satisfy your sweet tooth. Dig into the Double Chocolate Fudge Cake and enjoy the rich layers of dark chocolate cream encased within layers of soft chocolate cake. 


Evenings at the restaurant are also a night to remember. Wind down with cocktails and a casual dinner while observing the magical cityscape sunset.(Nov 2020)

data.title: The Garden
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Miso Eggplant, Smashed Avocado, The Garden Burger, Wild Berry Clafoutis
data.ABOUT:
Indulge with zero guilt at The Garden with its vast offerings of healthy selections to complete your wellness journey. Situated within a charming colonial-era building, The Garden serves up comfort food in a bright and airy milieu. Focusing on wellness, enjoy small plates, delicious tartines and burgers, delectable mains and desserts before washing it all down with detoxifying mocktails and well-balanced cocktails here at The Garden.

A great place for brunch and weekend catch-ups with family and friends, The Garden is a leisurely stroll away from Sofitel SPA. Start off with a small platter of Miso Eggplant. Made of whipped ricotta, pomegranate, pickled shallot and asian slaw, this delightful dish is the perfect appetiser to be shared. For salad lovers, The Garden Salad is a sumptuous mix of mesclun, olives, and roasted pumpkin accompanied by a variety of nutritious greens. Layered on toasted sourdough and topped with poached eggs, the Smashed Avocado is a well-loved favourite that is as healthy as it is tasty. 

Satisfy your carnivorous cravings with The Garden Burger or a large plate of Wagyu Hanger Steak. Sandwiched between two fluffy toasted sesame buns, The Garden Burger features a wagyu beef patty atop melted aged cheddar. Make sure you leave room for dessert with the Wild Berry Clafoutis. (Nov 2020)

data.title: The Gong by Drinks & Co. (Duo)
data.Cuisine: Bar, Modern European, Fusion, International, Steakhouse, Pizza
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Pet Friendly, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Mushroom Pizza, Singapore Sling, Mojito, Salt and Pepper Squid
data.ABOUT:
Named after the commanding sound of the famed East Asian instrument, this restaurant has made a name for itself as one of the “It” places in Singapore’s drinking scene. Located in the swish Duo Galleria, this spot has made a name for itself as one of the few places in the city that offer a modern drinking experience with a nod to our roots. With an exposed brick interior, sleek lighting, and a posh feel, this spot wouldn’t look out of place on the streets of Melbourne.

The seafood and poultry dishes are popular choices, and for good reason! Both dishes offer a hefty portion of meat without an exorbitant price tag. There are even gluten-free and plant-based options for diners who have dietary restrictions. The Mushroom Pizza is great for sharing. The crust is made in-house, and makes for a light base that doesn’t overpower the earthy mushroom toppings.

Come here for a tipple or two, or dance the night away to some downtempo funk. Whether you’re in the mood for wine or whisky, a Singapore Sling or a Mojito, the staff will be happy to make recommendations.

data.title: The Grand Lobby (Raffles Hotel)
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Scones with Clotted Cream and Rose Petal Jam, Rouge Opera Tea, Vert Provence Tea
data.ABOUT: Indulge in a timeless experience in the restored Grand Lobby of the iconic Raffles Singapore. The grandeur of floor-to-ceiling Victorian pillars, bathed in soft daylight streaming through the skylight make it a truly refined and unique destination for their signature Raffles Afternoon Tea.Enjoy a mouthwatering assortment of flavourful finger sandwiches and buttery scones, all made in house. Fragrant and delicate, The Grand Lobby's rose petal jam is worth every inch of sweetness. Don't miss the variety of cakes that are both light and airy, as well as dark and flavourful.Pair your small bites with The Grand Lobby's carefully curated collection of exquisitely perfumed international teas. We recommend the Rouge Opera, a mesmerising blend consisting of South African Red Rooibos with notes of red fruit and vanilla. For something lighter, try the Vert Provence, a green tea blended with Provencal fruits, with a fragrance that's both fruity and grassy. Alternatively, order a glass of bubbly that's sure to keep you in high spirits throughout the afternoon. (Jun 2020)

data.title: The Grumpy Bear @ Ang Mo Kio
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Large Parties (16+)
data.Address: 216 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 4#01-03Kebun Baru Community CentreSingapore (569897)                                                Map
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Ultimate Carbonara, Prawn Aglio Olio, Seafood Salad, Fish & Chips, Cajun Chicken Chop, Atlantic Salmon Fillet, Grass-Fed Ribeye Steak, Japanese Tori Chicken
data.ABOUT:
If you’re looking to forego all the frills and just tuck into simple comfort food, The Grumpy Bear is the place for you. Featuring a wide range of dishes from the West, you’ll have little trouble finding something you like. And you won’t have to burn a hole in your wallet to get a good meal, too – prices at this cosy café are plenty affordable.
It’s hard not to love The Grumpy Bear; a meal there is as unpretentious and unfussy as can be, and will be as kind on your wallet as it is to your stomach. Good food, good prices – what more could you ask for, really? (Sep 2018)

data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly

data.title: The Guild
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Freshly shucked Oysters, Smoked Mushroom Salad, General Tso’s Frog Legs, “Marrow” Bruschetta, Ham Dan Fried Chicken, BBQ Skate, Signature Mac n’ Cheese
data.ABOUT: A collaboration with Hong Kong’s Young Master Brewery and Chef Vinny Lauria, The Guild is a restaurant and bar serving contemporary comfort food and a comprehensive drinks selection with old fashioned hospitality and warmth. With a mission to celebrate the craft of small scale producers, the Guild highlights locally sourced ingredients, independent craft beer, all-natural wines, and cocktails based on small-batch spirits. Housed at 55 Keong Saik Road, the setting marries the conviviality of a Victorian public house with homey touches of a Peranakan shophouse. (Aug 2019)

data.title: The Gyu Bar
data.Good For: Business Meetings, Fine Dining, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Karubi, Wagyu Tongue, Sirloin Steak, Pork Neck, Wagyu Tataki
data.ABOUT: Pure creamy and melt-in-your-mouth indulgence. And no, we’re not talking about ice cream here. The Gyu Bar brings in one of the rarest wagyu in town — Wa-OH beef from the Kumamoto prefecture on Kyushu Island. If you’re wondering why this matters, imagine this: the super fresh air and pure, pristine waters make the perfect environment for grazing cows. The meat here is also extra-tender, thanks to a special blend of feed given to the animals. At Gyu Bar, you’ll find some surprising cuts as well as the usual ribeye and sirloin fillets. Try the tomo-sankaku (a cut near the bottom round). A considerably rare cut, the glistening meat is juicy and buttery, served with a crusty sear. A little dab of wasabi helps balance out the fattiness of the meat. There’s also shin-tama, which comes from the knuckle, as well as leaner cuts like short plate. Besides beef, Gyu Bar also offers other meats like pork neck or tontoro. (Feb 2019)

data.title: The Halia at Singapore Botanic Gardens
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Halia Chilli Crab Spaghettini, Sticky Toffee Pudding with Butterscotch and Vanilla Ice Cream, Sous Vide Chicken Leg, Celeriac Lagsana, Ginger Nougat Parfait
data.ABOUT:
The word ‘halia’ means ginger in Malay. While this is a reference to the world-famous Ginger Garden of the Singapore Botanic Gardens where the restaurant is located, the word itself has long been synonymous with comfort for many -- ginger tea, ginger massages. And if comfort is what you are looking for after a hard day at work or a long afternoon of relentless shopping, The Halia is the ideal place for you to kick back and relax in style.
In the historic UNESCO World Heritage Site that is the Singapore Botanic Gardens, The Halia is an inviting space with lush foliage complemented by wood-carved tables and open verandas. This matches the menu well, as modern European cuisine with touches of Asian influences are on offer. Favourites include the Halia Chilli Crab Spaghettini and the Sticky Toffee Pudding with Butterscotch and Vanilla Ice Cream, so be sure to try them. The piquant flavours of the former ensure that you get a taste of one of Singapore’s most beloved dishes, while keeping your hands clean, and the latter is a throwback to a more decadent colonial past.
In keeping with the name, ginger is very much on the menu, with the irreplaceable underground root used in main courses, salads and drinks. The health benefits of ginger are multifold, from relieving digestive problems such as nausea to aiding the loss of appetite, motion sickness, and pain. It certainly is comforting to have all these great upsides in mind as you sip a ginger-infused cocktail, take in the luxuriant foliage, and relax in The Halia. (Aug 2016)

data.title: The Hideout at District 20
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Casual Dining, Kid Friendly, Drinks, Private Functions
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Warm Seafood Salad, Sausage Sampler, Pork Knuckle, Chicken Wings, Aglio Olio
data.ABOUT:
Tucked away on Jalan Pemimpin lies The Hideout at District 20, a secluded bistro where you’re invited to let your hair down and put your feet up while relaxing over a pint of ice-cold beer or a plate of nosh. 
 
Decked out in leather sofas and a towering wall of liquor, this eatery has successfully created an environment that feels more like a good friend’s hangout nook. This is especially true on nights where the live music is played or English football is televised on the large screens, drawing a buzzy crowd of people who are just one conversation away from becoming your new friends. 
 
Then tuck into the restaurant’s extensive menu which spans a collection of burgers, bar bites, grilled meats, pasta, and even Japanese bento boxes. Some of the well-loved dishes (and deservedly so!) include the Warm Seafood Salad where scallops, shrimp, squid, and crab meat are served alongside warm garlic bread. The Sausage Sampler is sure to become your next favourite thing, with an expansive variety of meats that include chicken mushroom sausage, pork chorizo, veal bratwurst, among others.  
 
Featuring an intoxicating blend of cold brews, good nosh, and a lively crowd, The Hideout at District 20 is one of our favourite Marymount-based hangouts that injects a dose of much-needed fun into the neighbourhood. (Jun 2018)

data.title: The Hitsuji Club
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Business Meetings, Casual Dining, Drinks
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Baby Lamb Chops, Lamb Fillet, Lamb Loin, Cheese Miso, Assorted Vegetables
data.ABOUT:
Marbled slabs of pork belly or premium beef cuts are usually the meats of choice at most Japanese BBQ restaurants. But over at The Hitsuji Club, it's all about lamb in varying cuts. This intimate 20-seater specialises in jingisukan, a popular Hokkaido dish where mutton is grilled over a skillet. The chef’s insistence to use only grain-fed, chilled baby lamb from Australia or New Zealand means you don’t get the gamey smell so often associated with this meat. Instead, the grilled lamb chops are juicy and tender, with a clean, milky taste. 

Try the specialty Jingisukan With Lamb Chop set, which comes with different cuts such as the fillet, loin, and chops. Grilled together with plump mushrooms and fresh vegetables for an added crunch, the set can be considered a delicious and satisfying meal on its own. If you’re still feeling a tad peckish, add on some cheese miso and lotus root chips for nibbles. (Mar 2019)

data.title: The Horse's Mouth
data.Good For: Casual Dining, Drinks, Private Functions, Romantic Dates
data.Address: 583 Orchard Road#B1-39Forum the Shopping MallSingapore (238884)                                                Map
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Bespoke Cocktails, Nonkotsu, Eihire, Bushi Tonkotsu Ramen (from Uma Uma Ramen), Grilled Wagyu Beef
data.ABOUT:
The first time we stepped into The Horse's Mouth, we were, quite honestly, stopped mid-gallop. A warm, smoothly finished wood bar, Shoji-inspired light fixtures that dominate the ceiling, and eclectic touches like the bright colour displays, evoke images of autumn and summer. Lit brightly enough for you to appreciate the details, but still seductively dark enough to leave plenty to the imagination, The Horse's Mouth is ahead of the pack when it comes to setting the scene for a great night out.
If you're a hungry horse, then don't fret. The snack menu is feedbag full of tasty, with the nonkotsu (chicken softbone), tatami iwashi (dried sardine crackers), and eihire (stingray fins) the ideal bar food to take the edge off. Feeling like you could eat a horse? We don't recommend that, but you'll be happy to know that you can order from Uma Uma's selection of umami ramen for something more robust.
As for the thirsty ones, well, the menu looked all well and delicious, but when a joint tells you it's a cocktail bar, then we believe that drinks have to be bespoke. You might have some trouble remembering what exactly was in them after all is said and done, but that's the price you pay for delectable cocktails that run the gamut of sweet, sour, fruity, or just straight up strong. Let them know what you want, and there'll be no horsing around.
If you're wondering why, or how, a place can be this slick (or why we made so many bad puns), our advice is not to look a gift horse in the mouth. Round up your drinking buddies, saddle up, and ride on down to The Horse's Mouth. We know a champion when we see one. (May 2014)

data.title: The Knolls
data.Good For: Al Fresco, Kid Friendly, Quiet Dinner, Romantic Dates
data.DISHES WE LOVE: Homemade Croquettes, Jumbo Lump Crab Cake, Seared Barramundi Fillet
data.ABOUT: Inspired by its seafront setting, guests can enjoy a refreshing Mediterranean dining experience in an intimate and inviting atmosphere at The Knolls at Capella Singapore. The Knolls is one of Singapore's finest Mediterranean restaurants with a showcase of authentic specialties from the Mediterranean Sea. (Feb 2019)

data.Good For: Al Fresco, City Views, Casual Dining, Drinks
